  356. Initially, I bought this (1) due to my previous experience with a Panasonic shaver; and (2) the great price on Amazon. I've had this shaver for about 9 months, and it does a good job. It works especially well (i.e. shaves closer) when using it in the shower with shaving cream. A single charge usually lasts me for about 2 weeks, so I have no complaints there. My biggest complaint is the cleaner/charger itself. When the unit is charging the shaver, it is loud. If you don't believe me, compare the level of noise when in the same room as the shaver is being cleaned to when the cleaner is done. Just don't be in the same room as the cleaner as it's charging the shaver. I find the noise level too high. Knowing what I know now, I probably wouldn't pay full retail for this shaver. It's not worth it. Thankfully on Amazon, it's discounted pretty heavily.
  357. First, a little background on my shaving history. I started around 14 with my Dad's standard rotary electric shaver, which he claimed was all I'd ever need to get the job done. In a sense, he was right; the shaver got the job done, but I now know that it takes a truly great product to get the job done WELL. I dabbled a bit with blade shaving but found it to be impractical and often painful. It was just not worth the extra effort to achieve a minor improvement in closeness. So I did what most men do: Take their dad's advice and continue on a path of a daily ritual of mediocrity and indifference. I used to dread waking up knowing that the task lay before me, just wanting to blink my eyes and have it be over. No longer. This product truly did change my whole perspective. Turning on this razor for the first time summoned a response akin to what an aviation engineer must have felt when he heard a jet engine for the first time...wow. The 13,000 RPM blades emit a futuristic whir that almost say \\"Shave with me, you won't be sorry.\\" And you won't. This was my first experience with a foil shaver so I was a bit dubious about their supposed performance. However, that soon passed after my first shave. I have NEVER had a shave as close or as painless. The combination of the swivel head that contours over your face with the high RPMs of the blade that capture even the toughest hairs make for an extremely close, comfortable shave. This thing is what George Jetson uses in the morning before he hops in his spaceship...it's that good. After I shaved with it the first time I could not stop running my hands over my face in amazement, and I still can't. If you've shaved with a rotary your whole life, you will not believe the difference in performance this foil razor gives. So as to not be long winded, the moral of the story is: Close, comfortable, convenient shave at a reasonable price. I can't compare it to some of the higher end competition, but I can say I couldn't imagine getting a closer shave than this (so why pay an extra $100 to test that theory?). Some Tips I've Learned After 3 Months of Use: -For the closest, most comfortable shave possible with this shaver, shave after your stubble has had 2 days to grow and shave with shaving gel/cream and hot water like a blade. I do mine in the shower. The 2 days of growth allows the shaver to capture the hairs much more easily and the gel helps give a comfortable, smooth shave. Follow up with an aftershave balm. I follow this ritual: After shaving Friday morning, I usually don't shave again until Monday morning, after which I get an amazing shave that puts a smile on my face and prepares me to face the challenges of the work week. -For daily shaves, use a pre-shave solution and shave dry. This is convenient and allows for maximum day-to-day performance. -Use the cleaning base after EVERY shave. When shaving dry, take the foil off and rinse out all the hairs before putting it back into the cleaning base. The most important thing this cleaning base does to your shaver is LUBRICATE. If you notice after the cleaning cycle is over, take the foil off and look at the blades in the light. The liquid on the blades is lubricant, and it will help tremendously to provide a smoother, closer shave as well as preserve the life of the blades. As a matter of fact, try an experiment. Rinse the blades and let them dry, then put the foil back on and turn on the shaver to listen to the blades. Now do the same after the shaver has been through a cleaning cycle. You will notice that without lubricant the blades actually give off a slight grinding, abrasive sound barely noticeable to the ear. It is noticeable to the face...trust me. Always use a properly lubricated shaver when you can. By rinsing after shaving and then putting your shaver in the cleaning base, you will prolong the life of the cleaning cartridges. -To best shave the sides of your cheeks along the jawline up the sideburns, I've found that pulling the skin to make it tighter actually doesn't result in the closest shave. Instead, move the shaver over the skin without stretching it. This makes the skin kind of roll underneath the shaver, then the 13,000 RPM blades make short work of the hairs. This pretty much wraps it up. I don't usually review products here on Amazon, but I do when I find them particularly noteworthy and I have something of substance to offer consumers. If you're still wondering whether or not to get this razor, take Nike's advice...Just Do It. Your face will thank you.

  364. I like this shaver. Have been using it for six months now and have no serious complaints. The shaver has pretty good battery life, I can get about three shaves before wanting to recharge. If I had to order this again I would not order it with the recharging/cleaning station; it is just not necessary and takes up space while not being used. The power cord is all I take with me when traveling. I clean the shaver head with a little liquid soap in the palm of my hand. With warm water flushed through the shaver head I operate the shaver while the foil is in the liquid soap. The shaver head foams up with the water and soap, and I just rinse it out in running warm water. It comes out pristine. For a good shave I use Williams Lektric Shave lotion. If there are any stray whiskers left I flush my face with water and shave again with just the water on my skin. I get ingrown whiskers really bad everytime I use a razor, so I just do not use a razor unless it's an emergency. When I do use a razor I get razor burn, and that does not happen with this shaver, or most shavers for that matter, and neither do the ingrown whiskers. I would not recommend using this shaver dry. The one or two times I have used it dry I felt the heat in the shaver foil. Heat equals friction, and that means wear and tear on the shaver head. So keep it cool and the shaver foil and blade should last a long time. Before this shaver I used Remington 304's for years and was quite happy with them, but their quality and durability seemed to go downhill over the last three of them I wore out. So I switched, and am glad I did.

The first time around for me, it looked like I was attacked by my girlfriend.<br /><br />Good luck
  368. I bought this shaver about six months ago and waited to see if I still liked it after some use before writing a review. My face is fairly sensitive and I've always had trouble in the summer. This shaver is the best thing since sliced bread. The shaver itself is probably a bit better than any other I've tried (Norelco, Braun, Grundig). The ability to use it with lather makes it fantastic. I really do get a shave as close as a razor - I can feel my skin against the direction of my beard and it feels smooth. I can also use an alcohol based after shave lotion and it doesn't burn. One other thing, I've found that the cheap shaving soap available in the grocery store works best.
  369. Hello,<br /><br />I bought this product to shave my head i had moles that kept getting cut with my regular razor. This product has been working great for me. It takes a little longer than shaving to get all the areas done but it does a good job. It works everywhere good except for my neck somtimes i have to carfully strech my skin and go agenst the gain to get the neck. the cleaning feature works great and i would recomend this product.

He's been bothering me since Christmas for a new shaver, so I let him get an early start for Father's day. This is a great find and cheaper than buying it in the store.
  377. I have had this razor for almost 3 years and just thought I would share how much I love it. It works great. Have never had one issue with it. When the faucet appears on the readout to indicate a self-cleaning is due, I just remove the foil and run the blades under hot water. This seems to satisfy it (the faucet picture disappears). I recharge it with the power cord.
  379. I bought this razor as a gift for my husband. He had an old chargeable razor for years and it finally broke.   381. This product is designed exceptionally well and performs to my highest expectations.   382. My 3+ year old Braun 7526 Syncro with Clean and Charge finally had enough. Prior to that was a blade preceeded by a Norelco.<br /><br />Lets jump back a few years and share my history...<br /><br />I have always broken out with razor burn and ingrown hairs on my neck for as long as I started growing facial hair. Cheap razors were terrable so I asked for an electric. The Norelco made it easier to shave but still had the issues. Several months later it was back to the blade. Someone suggested a foil shaver and, after much hesitation, I purchased the Braun. Wow! What an improvement over the blade and rotory shavers. I have been happily using it daily for almost 4 years. Dare I say...almost enjoy shaving. Razor burn is almost non-existant unless you grind away in an area for too long a time (come back to the area 15 minutes later helps), ingrown hairs are 98% cured, and it shaved closer than a rotory with only a few passes. A win/win combination. The cleaning system is great except when away from home and you have to do it manually.<br /><br />That brings us to the present...<br /><br />The Braun has hit the snooze button and no longer wants to get up in the morning with me. After many hours of research I thought I wanted another Braun...their top of the line Pulsonic model. Almost bought one based on a few blogs on the web. I did cringe at the asking price of $250 - $300 suggested retail. I have always enjoyed Panasonic products and noticed this razor at half the asking price of the Braun. It seemed too good to be true, but Panasonic products have never let me down yet. I gave it a try, knowing I could try it for 30 days and send it back if unhappy. I had nothing to lose.<br /><br />I have had it a week now and nobody is taking this shaver away from me. I dare you to compare the 2 razors back to back and honestly say the Braun is worth double the price. They are, in my opinion, in the same class. The Panasonic is quieter both shaving and in the cleaning stand. It shaves closer and cuts more hair on the first pass, eliminating a 3rd or 4th pass. The Braun would sometimes knick my adams apple or lip and I have tried to get the Panasonic to do it but it wont (call me stupid). Since I dont have to shave 3, 4, or 5 times on my neck, the razor burn is gone. The ingrown hairs are 99% gone (I have had only one this past week). The cleaning gets the blades cleaner and they smell soapy clean and not chemically clean. The best part, a bonus if you will, is the Panasonic is water-resistant. Not only can you rinse the head off underwater at home or on the road, but you can shave in the shower or use shaving creams or lotions (gels are not recommended). The top of the line Braun can be rinsed under water but not used \\"wet\\" or with creams or lotions. The only drawback I could find is the travel bag they supply. I was hoping they could have supplied a better case to hold the cord and shaver for extended trips. Not a big deal though, on a big trip...I will have a big suitcase so I'm sure there will be plenty of room in there for a cord.<br /><br />In conclusion, a great shaver with all the current technology and features offered by the competition at a reasonable asking price.<br /><br />EDIT - MONDAY JANUARY 21, 2008<br />Since purchasing, this razor still continues to be my favorite. I have now started using it \\"wet\\" by warming my face with hot water, then applying a Neutragena shaving cream. The results are better. It shaves more hairs on the first pass, the cream eliminates any friction, and gives me the closest shave yet with an electric (some areas of the face feel like I shaved with a blade).<br /><br />EDIT - SUNDAY JANUARY 18, 2009<br />Still loving it and using it everyday. However, the wife ran it through the front load washer tonight. It is now very clean. Still runs but needs a new set of blades. For added measure and the price of new blades and foil, I found a really good deal on the ES8228S shaver. The only difference between the two is the ES8228S adds a zippered vinyl travel case (vs cloth bag with draw strings) and the head has independent floating foil (each of the 3 foils is on their own suspension to track the curves of the face better).th draw strings) and the head has independent floating foil (each of the 3 foils is on their own suspension to track the curves of the face better).
  383. I bought this product for my boyfriend who needs to shave often but was always cutting himself. His old electric left his face feeling whiskery even right after he shaved. Read other reviews about the Panasonic being almost like a razor so I decided to try and he LOVES it.....doesn't even mind shaving. Plus he can used this wet (for a real close shave) or dry!
  384. I purchased the ES8109S Vortex after reviewing several brands and reading hunderds of reviews. First use, perfect shave. Yes it misses a few hairs under the chin, but I have never owned an electric that didn't. It is the nature of how they work. A few passes, perfect. I am shaving my head daily. It works great in the shower with a little soap. Smooth as a blade, takes about 4 minutes for whole head. I would highly recommend this shaver for those who want an electric option for head shaving. Looks like I'm getting 5 shaves (face and head) on a charge. I have read a lot about the noise from this and other panasonics. I did not mind the noise. It was not as loud as I expected after reading the reviews. My preference, clean the shaver under water most days. run it through the cleaner once a week.
  385. To preface, this shaver is the first electric shaver I've used in probably a good decade. I had a cheapie Norelco years and years ago when I first hit puberty, but I quickly changed to razors. My reasons for doing so were just about the reasons of everyone who prefers razors: My beard grows thick and quick, and within a week I've usually got a good \\"crumb catcher\\" going. Beyond that, razors are just the smoothest shave you'll get, even with the risk of nicks and razor-burn. After finding this on a deal through Amazon, somewhere in the low $90's I believe, I felt like it was time to try electrics once again since shaving every other day was a losing battle for me and I had resorted to once a week grooming. I figured for the price, it better be pretty darn good - $90 (on sale) is no small drop in the bucket for me when it comes to this stuff. Well, I set aside my favorite blade (Mach 3 Turbo for me) and prepared for the worst. Like every new shaving method, it takes about a month for the beard to adjust, and the first shave wasn't entirely pleasant (as I recall from my previous foray with electrics a decade ago). But, now speaking about 4 weeks into it, I can honestly say I'm impressed. On my cheeks and face, it's almost impossible to tell between the razor and Panasonic's little beauty. I've tried it in the shower (yes, it is completely waterproof) and with shaving cream and all sorts of lubricants, but for my thick beard I found that it just didn't get close enough and took too long with all the water and creams. My favorite method, I've found, is dry shaving at the end of the day/beginning when your face isn't so sensitive, and just running the blades under some cold water now and then (both to clean them momentarily, lubricate your skin just a tad, and keep them cool - the blades do get hot) while simultaneously moving it in small circles over the area you want shaved (almost like brushing your teeth). There are still a few trouble spots underneath my chin and on my neck that are difficult to get without stretching my skin quite a bit, but they were problem areas even when I was using a razor. What's more, and this is definitely my favorite attribute; with the method above there's so little irritation (only on the outskirts underneath my chin) that I don't feel like I've been mauled by some ravenous feline after shaving! It's fantastic. Particularly above the chin, I can barely tell it's cutting the hairs, and don't feel bothered even during the process. The base itself fits in a corner, is fairly compact (about the size of one of those scented candles in a jar), and does its job well. The cleaner does not use alcohol to clean, but a detergent solution that uses water housed in a small tank also in the base. And to top it off, you're looking at a cheaper upkeep than blades. The detergent packs are cheap ($15 for a set of 3, each one lasts a month), and you need to replace the foil (once a year, with the blades once every two years (~$50 for both foil and blades). So that's $110/year max for shaving, compared to $180/year for cartridge blades. If there are any Cons for me, it would be the following: -While in operation it is a tad loud. Not annoyingly so, but it's a very high frequency pulsating noise (that you won't notice in about 30 seconds into the shave), but afterwards (especially if you shave in a smaller room) everything sounds distorted because of it for about a minute. -The cleaning base is also a little noisy. You won't hear it down the stairs or anything, but if you're in the next room and this buzzing keeps coming up, it's the base and the shaver cleaning itself. -The same button that turns the shaver on also turns on the \\"manual cleaning\\" mode if you press it for 5 seconds. This is NOT a shaving mode, but a cleaning mode to use when you don't have the base. I have not had any trouble with it accidentally changing modes so far, but the manual does warn that the cleaning modeis not designed for shaving. Overall, I've had a rather pleasant and refreshing experience with the shaver. While occasionally I may return to razors if I need that ultra-smooth shave (black tie events), this thing is now my bread and butter. It does a grand job once you're used to it, and I can't imagine going a full week without shaving again. The only area this thing has left to surprise me in is how long it lasts without being recharged as I haven't had any extended trips, but I don't see it failing me there either (I use about 20-30% of the battery per shave, at about 7-minutes a shave). I highly recommend it for anyone who's looking at an electric shaver and is pondering whether it's worth the ~$100 investment. I found it to be.
  386. I've used Braun shavers for a few years, and prior to that Norelco. The cleaning system for the Braun always irritated me, due to the evaporation of the solution. However, it was giving me a very close shave until, I believe, the battery finally lost enough power. Despite the cleaning problem, I was willing to buy the $200+ Braun shaver since I like their foil system. But I've always wanted to try a wet/dry shaver, and Amazon had this razor on sale for $88, so I thought I'd give it a try. I was really suprised how well the shaver works wet. The foil system is very similar to the Braun, and its easy to clean either with the cleaning unit or under water. Plus the cleaning solution seems to last forever - its been about 6 weeks and I haven't had to buy a new cartridge. So why 4 stars? It doesn't work very well dry, so you have to spend extra time in the shower in the morning and buy gel for a close shave. Because the blade and foil are very sharp and have a high RPM, you get cuts periodically...just like a blade! Also, my cleaning unit will only clean if I unplug it and plug it in again. Very odd design. Finally, I've never seen those cleaning cartridges for sale anywhere, which is kind of annoying.
  387. Now, I suppose if you buy this razor thinking it's going to cure diseases, fix your car, or get you that long sought-after menage a trois, then your expectations are too high and you're going to be disappointed. Reading some of these reviews, I was prepared to find your average electric razor.<br /><br />This is the third electric razor I've owned and second Panasonic. I look at these Brauns and Remingtons and they just don't seem to be worth it. Especially Brauns. $200 or more for a razor?! Seriously?<br /><br />I use electric razors because my beard requires hot steam treatment prior to shaving with a regular razor. It seems like no matter what I do, whether it's using special shaving cream, hot wash cloths on my face, the finest disposable razors, etc, that I get nicks, ingrown hairs, and general irritation if I use a regular disposable razor. So, I turned to electric razors.<br /><br />No, you don't get as close a shave as you would with a disposable. But, if you didn't know that, then you've never used an electric razor before. However, all of that being said, this is the best electric razor I've ever used. I've used it for over a month now and am extrememly satisfied with it. The shave is close and smooth. The razor is easy to use and versatile. As I said, I have a tough beard and sensitive skin. This razor does the best job with those weird little hairs on my neck and has yet to give me an ingrown hair.<br /><br />It's not \\"one-pass shaving\\" that's for sure. But, then, I don't know an electric razor that is. But it is pretty fast, I think. And smooth. The pivoting head is easy to use. And, the flip trimmer on the back can take care of those pesky longer neck hairs as well as trip up side burns. I even use it to even out my mustache and goatee between trims.<br /><br />The charger/cleaner is easy to use and does a great job. I wish it was faster. I love the complaints about the noise it makes. I mean, seriously? Where do you live, in an isolation chamber? For those of us that live in cities near other people and stuff, I don't think this is noisy. It certainly isn't nosier than my television. But, I used this for over a month and cleaned the razor each day. The filter lasted around 30 days, as advertised. My razor was always clean and ready to use the next morning.<br /><br />I think this is an excellent razor. And, with the discount Amazon is giving, I think it's a no-brainer to buy it. I got the whole thing with another coupon for $75. Maybe that's why I like it so much. In any case, it really is the best razor I ever bought. So glad I got it. Too many nitpickers around here complaining about stuff that doesn't matter.t live in cities near other people and stuff, I don't think this is noisy. It certainly isn't nosier than my television. But, I used this for over a month and cleaned the razor each day. The filter lasted around 30 days, as advertised. My razor was always clean and ready to use the next morning. I think this is an excellent razor. And, with the discount Amazon is giving, I think it's a no-brainer to buy it. I got the whole thing with another coupon for $75. Maybe that's why I like it so much. In any case, it really is the best razor I ever bought. So glad I got it. Too many nitpickers around here complaining about stuff that doesn't matter.
  388. I've been using a blade since I was 18 years old. For the years before that, it was a hand me down Norelco rotary from my dad. The wet shave option on the Panasonic is better than my blade. I used Mach 3 then switched to one of the 5 blade razors a few months ago. The Panasonic does a better job in less time. It only took a few days for my skin to get used to the electric razor.   389. This is my 2nd Panasonic shaver and it's just as good or better than the first. My first shaver lasted about four years and had one blade/screen replacement. It got to the point that the batteries wouldn't hold a charge and the shaver wasn't running at full speed. I was sad to see my older razer go since it had the great induction charging that was the halmark of older Panasonic razors. I started my search for a new shaver and came across this shaver. I was skeptical at first about the cleaning system since I hate spending money on crap that I don't need. After reading reviews on the shaver, plus the discount Amazon had, I took the plunge. It's like I have my old shaver back. It goes through my face hair w/ out shuddering and leaves my face smooth. I also like that the cleaning carts are only about $12 for three of them. From other reviews I have read you don't have to change the water once a month. You can wait till the light comes on and then change it. Overall, it's a great buy and I'm looking forward to more years with another wonderful razor.
  390. Ok, after using the 'cheaper' offerings in the Norelco brand of shavers for the last 20+ years I wanted to upgrade. After reading all the positive reviews here I thought I'd give this one a try. It is cheaper than the Braun and the arcitec and rates just as good (if not better). I knew I'd have to give my face a chance to 'adapt' to the foil vs. the Norelco rotary blades. Well after 28 days this shaver is going back. It has not been able to shave nearly as close as my 8 year old Norelco and this shaver has a design flaw. The Panasonic shaver has no collector for the beard clippings. If you hold the shaver just right you will get shaver clippings all over your face, your clothes, your sink, etc. I had to follow up with a razor after each and every shave. The Panasonic was never able to properly shave my chin. I can't comment if it is this shaver or this type of shaver (foil). I did read in a consumer's report where it's best to stick to one type of electric shaver, so I may be destined to stay with a rotary shaver. Regardless, with this Panasonic I was covered in clippings at the end of each morning's shave and I don't find this acceptable.
  391. This razor gave me a shave equal to or better than any shave I've gotten without using a regular blade (even a somewhat dull blade). My beard is probably average; not too thick, not too thin. If I don't have anything special going on I can go two days after shaving with a blade with only the mustache / goatee area looking kind of scraggly on the second day. But I have to shave every day when using an electric. I've only had three electric razors in over 30 years of shaving; a cheap rotary non-cordless Norelco, a Braun 6520 and now this one. I have also used a blade between razor purchases, when the razors needed new parts and on special occasions just because it looks better. The Norelco may or may not have done a better job on my neck due to the rotary heads but overall I recall it giving me an average to poor shave even after replacing the heads. The Braun gave me a great shave and I would still be using it if I were not concerned about how much longer the battery would last. It used to provide about ten shaves per charge but now it's down to maybe four. Since the Braun needed a new screen and blades I figured the money would be better spent buying a new razor. Braun has priced their razors out of the range I'll pay for shaving my face so I read the reviews and bought the Panasonic. The Panasonic has been great for the two weeks I've used it. After the first two or three uses I noticed my neck was kind of itchy which has since subsided. I suspect it was due to pushing too hard or maybe my face just needed to get used to the new razor. Or maybe it had nothing to do with razor, who knows. It is a little louder than the Braun or at least a different pitch but I don't think that it would be any more liable to wake someone up in an adjacent room. The power button certainly is in an odd place where I suspect most men put their thumb when shaving and I did shut it off by mistake once. To avoid that from happening a minor change in how you holdthe razor is required which is to shift the thumb closer to the head where at least Panasonic thinks your thumb should be. I like to hold the razor so that it does not touch the palm of my hand and only my thumb and fingers are gripping it but I have tried a golf club grip a few times which worked fine but will take some getting used to. I have only shaved dry and probably won't use it wet, with or without lather. I have also not used the cleaning feature yet but I do like the base for charging and to have somewhere to put the razor when not in use. I suspect the cleaning feature will be useful if and when I use it but the documentation shows the razor can be easily cleaned with soup and water under the faucet. Either way, it will be nice to be able to thoroughly clean it and not have to rely on the dumb little brushes. All in all I have no complaints about this razor and I would recommend it to anyone who does not expect a shave as good as a regular blade. If there's an electric razor out there that does that good of a job I would like to know about it. Until then, I'll be happy using this one.
  392. I purchased the Panasonic ES8109S Vortex Wet/Dry Shaver in mid-December 2008 at a great price. I took advantage of free shipping and my shaver arrived sooner than the estimated date. This shaver is the best of the many electric shavers I have owned. Its considerable power makes shaving quick and as close as I've ever had. And the HydraClean System is amazing. Unfortunately, I have yet to find a Target, Wal-Mart or similar discount store that stocks replacement foils and blades or cleaning solution for the HydraClean system, but that is no major problem since these items are readily available at good prices via Amazon. I recommend this product without reservation.
  393. My Facial Background: I have very sensitive skin, I've never been able to shave more than once a week due to skin irritation because I would get those water pimples that would make the area painful if I shaved against the grain with a razor or by using those electric razors from the 90's. Luckily I never suffered from Razor burn or Ingrowns. Due to that I learned to shave never going against the grain with a razor and that has let me shave my face twice a week problem free, if I shaved more than twice... skin irritation. Then I recieved this bad boy as a Father's day gift and now after a couple of months usage I have to say I'm pretty impressed; electric razors have come a long way. I won't say this is a miracle razor, because it isn't, but it allows me to shave my face against the grain for a much closer shave than I was getting with my razor with the grain. That now allows for a smoother feeling and I look better til my next shave. I also have noticed that I can shave my face more frequently as well, every other day bringing it to 3 times a week instead of the 2 before hand. Altho I will admit that I also use Neutrogena after shave lotion which helps out greatly. What I mean by no miracle razor, is that if you have sensitive skin, it isn't going to cure it. It has allowed me an extra shave a week and my face feeling smoother than my previous method, but I still can not shave every single day because I will get irritated. I'm not knocking the razor, it's awesome, just making sure you are realistic in your expectations. The benefits this electric has provided me has made me retire my razor permanently. I defintely recommend giving this razor a try, especially if you tried electrics in the past and thought they were garbage, times have changed my friends!

  399. This is the second Panasonic I bought. Last one is 8 years old and still works fine. SO i brought this one for my teenager. He loves it. He is amazed with the clean shave he gets with his razor. This is a self cleaning device. I would not hesitate to buy one for myself again in the future.
  400. I am writing this review after using the shaver for last 10 months! Frankly speaking, this is how long it took for me to realize the full potential of this amazing shaver. For the first couple of months I thought I wasted my money. I just wanted to use it for a few more months and switch back to blades. But.... in last 2 months, I am getting the best shave ever! I realized that you have to know the grain of your beard to get the best of this shaver. Recently I switched to one of those foamless shaving gels which helps me to figure out which way I should move. Since then, I am getting the closet shave. I will highly recommend this shaver... but please try foam-less Gel to get the closest shave!<br /><br />And one tip that will save you some money - dont use the Vortex cleaning system as frequently as the manual says. I use it once in 2 weeks. Other times I just clean the shaver with my hands under running water using regular hand soap. I have changed the cartridge after 10 months and blades are still like new!<br /><br />P.S. - The trimmer is one heck of an utility! Its really neat.
  401. I was going to buy the Braun Pulsonic until I read the reviews here and on other Web providers. They convinced me the 8109 was worth the purchase. Note that this shaver is the same as their more expensive 8228 except for a wood trim and case color on the latter. Out of box set up took 10 minutes to read and do. Charged up fully in 30 minutes even tho literature says \\"up to an hour\\". Wet shaves are great but even dry this shaver is without pulling and takes little effort for a shave second only to a blade. Putting in a new cartridge every month for the cleaning system is a minor nag but you can also rinse in tapwater. With a great shave, the ability to go into the shower with you, and a price well below The Braun, Panasonic has the winner here. To be fair, I did not shave with the Pulsonic and took the recommendation of others who had.
  402. so expensive. just crazy but this is what our son wanted.. oddly enough he barely uses it. i just can understand why a razor costs so much
  403. I replaced a Braun with this Panasonic and have been very happy. It is quieter and shaves closer. The blades seem to last longer too. I have had it for a couple of years and still performs like new.
  404. I owned this razor for over a year and I've been very pleased. However, I wish I hadn't purchased the cleaning station as it is an expensive way to clean it when liquid detergent would have worked as well. The cleaning station isn't poorly made, just unnecessary.
  405. Having the cleaning system is an added bonus. The panasonic razor is a great razor! it is also easier to store!
  406. I bout this 3 years ago and the best investment in years. I was paying 24.00 bucks for Gillette. They hardly lasted a week. This was a good buy, maybe 250 bucks and 3 years later, still going strong. Never really used the cleaning kit, just hose off in the sink.
  407. Have had two wet/dry shavers, the only reason I bought this one several years ago is I left the first one in a hotel room. I just replaced foils and blades, its like new again. Very good shaver lasts 2 weeks on a full charge using every other day. love it.
  408. Most electric razors cut up my neck but this one does awesome especially in the shower, love that it can be used wet. using it in Afghanistan now good for on the go
  409. I've had this for awhile. The tank stopped working within 6 months. But the shaver has been plugging along and it works quite well. I use it every morning. Glad I have it. Reasonably priced and does a good job.
  410. I am used to Gillette Mach3 for last 5 years or so and wanted to try something new that is maintainence free. I decided to try this one based on many positive reviews from users & a positive fan following over here. However, I am little disappointed with the results. I just got the shaver and tried it three times since. The facial shave seems to be quite good either on wet or dry shave but lot of neck hair were left even after 4-5 passes. No irritation or razor burn or nicks ( normally caused by Gillette Mach3) on the face even after 2-3 consecutive attempts. frankly it feels quite good for the face! However the experience on shaving the neck hair is totally opposite. It almost started bleeding after so many tries but I could not get a clean shave on the neck at all. I am in a fix here. I will try it for a few more days and then will decide whether its a keeper. Any suggestions are welcome, as I really don't want to return it.
  411. Been using this shaver now for 2 weeks and I love it! Used for both the head and face. Works exceptionally well to shave the head - wet or dry. As with all electric shavers, it has difficulty with neck hair. The cleaning system is fantastic - used about every 3-4 days to clean the shaver. An excellent value in this price range. In fact, I would put it up against the $180.00 Braun in all aspects!
  412. My credentials: 40 yrs. shaving (the 1st 25 years only with a blade.) I was so obsessed with closeness that I used to shave with a badger brush and shaving soap using a Hoffritz single blade. (This is as close as a barber's straight blade.) I have tried just about all the shavers since then. Remingtons, Norelcos (through the Bond, James Bond model), all the Brauns through the Activator, and the last 3 or 4 Panasonic models. Braun, with its interceptor blades, convinced me that shaving electrically was quicker, less bloody, and more comfortable than my blades, along with an acceptable shave. Panasonic's shavers convinced me that shaving with an electric could come very close to the quality of a blade. However, there was always a problem. The first few ultrasonics I had had terrible batteries. Another one went dead after a year (and had the reputation for doing that too). And the last one (I'm too lazy to look up that number) was a step backwards and never shaved very close. I got the ES8109s for around $86 here at Amazon before Christmas and was delighted. It fit perfectly in my hand, had the closest shave I have experienced so far, was good around the neck, and was comfortable. I always liked the cleaning system but cleaned and charged my shaver in the cleaner only once a week (every Sunday). Daily, I would brush out the whiskers. Unfortunately, after only 3 months, I already felt that the blades needed to be replaced. After 6 months, I can barely get an acceptable shave at all, having to go over and over the same area and still not get a close shave. This is not acceptable since (it seems to me at least) Panasonic's replacement blade/screens are the most expensive. The Brauns always lasted me between 18 months to 2 years. I am now debating whether to give this shaver one more try by replacing the blades or try a Braun 360 instead. (I refuse to buy the Braun Pulsonic since they feel very cheap in the hand, in my opinion, and have integrated blades/shaver screens that cannot be cleaned out with a brush.) This is really frustrating since Panasonic makes wonderful shavers but always appears to have an \\"Achille's heel.\\"
  413. Shaves very closely without irritating the skin. Used wet with lather it glides very smoothly but doesn't seem to shave any closer than dry, and using it wet takes extra time fussing with lather and cleanup so I usually just pick it up and shave without water. The cleaning unit has a complex cycle that whirs and clicks for over an hour, but it cleans the shaver well. This shaver is much less expensive than the top-end Braun, which I haven't tried, but I'm glad I bought this one as I don't see how an electric shaver could perform much better.
  414. Either wet or dry, this shaver didn't do a good job for me. I wasn't able to get a close shave at all. The last straw was when I did one of those side by side tests. I shaved with an old dull Gillette razor on half my face and this thing on the other. The powerless, old blade won hands down. My wife saw the difference immediately.<br /><br />The above, of course, were my results and it may have a lot to do with my facial make up. However, there were other things that I disliked:<br /><br />-- When the shaver is at full charge it blinks all the time. I found that pretty annoying in the middle of the night if I happened to have the bathroom door open.<br /><br />-- One of the reasons I got the shaver was to save money in the long run on blades. However, the cleaning cartridge doesn't have a long life and would have cost me as well.<br /><br />-- The cleaning system takes about an hour and is pretty noisy.<br /><br />-- I found the shaver screen got hot pretty quickly, even when using it wet.<br /><br />So, for me, it didn't work too well. I've shipped it back and gone back to my old blade razor.
  415. OK, so I have decided to stop being a review parasite (I often look to reviews to help me in buying decisions, but don't write my own review). I have been using the Panasonic E8109S shaver for about a week now, and here is my 2 cents. 1st, in my opinion, based on using two rotary electric razors (Norelco), 2 foil razors (Braun), and now a 3rd foil razor, none give as close of a shave as a razor blade, but if you give your face about a month to adapt you can generally get a good shave from the better (more expensive) electrics. I prefer the foil razors, as they seem to me to shave closer, and it is easier to maneuver them around the ears and nose without leaving behind hairs. Now on to the review. As stated above, I had 2 Braun shavers. Braun 1 was an excellent shaver that cost around $80 - $100. It gave a great shave, held a charge for a couple of weeks, and quietly hummed when operating. It came with the Braun cleaning system. When it's motor failed after a year of operation I bought Braun 2, which was a cheaper razor (around $60 I think). It didn't hold a charge as long, didn't have the cleaning system, didn't shave as well and was much louder. The lesson here is you get what you pay for, and name brand doesn't guarantee anything. Luckily I realized Braun's warranty is 2 years, not 1 as I had thought, so I got Braun 1 repaired for free (they even mailed it to me after fixing it) and I got another 3 years or so use before the on/off switch got stuck in the on position, and I started using Braun 2 again. Needless to say, it didn't take long before I was ready to shell out some cash for a better razor. Initially I was planning on getting another higher priced Braun, but was pulled to the Panasonic by a couple of points. First, it is cheaper than Braun's with comparable features, and I was intrigued by the ability to shave using shaving cream again. Since the Panasonic sells for $100 (although I got it for $73), I will compare it to Braun 1, which was similarly priced. I cannot compare it to today's Braun models, so you will have to look to reviews of those products, although I doubt they are much different from the model I owned. It was a 4000 series (I don't remember the exact number, but I still have Braun 2, which is model 5770). Cleaning System: I much prefer the cleaning system that comes with the Panasonic, as the base is more square, and takes up less room than the rounded Braun base, and more importantly it has rubber feet that keep it in place when the razor is being cleaned. I had to wedge the Braun cleaner against something, or else it would slide across my sink from the vibrations caused by the razor running. It also seemed louder than the Panasonic, but since it died a couple of years ago, I may be remembering that part incorrectly. Ergonomics: The Panasonic is a clear winner here as well. Not only is the razor noticeably lighter, it is skinnier, with a contoured shape for easy gripping, and a rubberized handle to reduce slipping. The bulkier, plastic handled Braun doesn't come close. Noise: Here I have to give the edge to the Braun. I don't think the Panasonic is much louder in Db, but it is much more high pitched, almost like a Dentist's drill and hair clippers had a baby, and this is it. Luckily I find that I get used to the sound about 2 seconds after I turn it on, probably because it is fairly quiet. It still beats Braun 2's roar. Shave: Again the Panasonic clearly beats Braun 2, but the more aptly compared Braun 1 gives it a run for it's money. I would call this a tie in the dry shave category. The dry shave was closer than the shave with shaving cream the first couple of days, but it seems to be shaving closer as I continue using shaving cream. I'm not sure if this is due to my face adjusting, me learning better technique, or what. I will say that I love using shaving cream again, and it is worth the miniscule difference that may occur in closeness. When I finish shaving, my face feels totally clean shaven, and I only notice the difference at the end of the day (stubble seems slightly more pronounced). Overall, I give the Panasonic 5 stars because it is reasonably priced, gives a great shave, holds it's charge for a long time and isn't unreasonably loud. The led that gives the remaining charge in 10% increments is also nice (and puts it in competition with higher priced competitors). On the negative side, the whine is a bit high pitched, and I cannot find replacement heads or cleaning solution at local stores, so will have to order it online - probably cheaper, but certainly not as convenient. All that to say I believe this is the best electric razor I have ever owned, and I won't hesitate to get another one in a few years when this one inevitably dies.
  416. I have only used rotary shavers before this one, and always seemed to get burned by them, and my neck would always get ripped up and blotchy red spots, which is really annoying when you have to shave to look clean for work, parties, events, etc. So I decided to try a foil shaver and see if it worked any better. Well, after using this shaver for almost two months now, I have to say it is the best shaver I could imagine using. I have not burned my neck since I began using it, and it stays much cleaner than my old razor, thanks to the HydraClean System and even the ease of cleaning with running under a faucet. I feel that foil shavers rinse cleaner than do rotary ones, and it is probably purely because the blades are more straight on these, whereas the old rotary shavers I had contained slightly curved blades, and could never seem to get fully clean. This is the type of shaver a person can use for years, with replacing the foils, of course, and be completely happy with. I would recommend this to anyone that swears by electrics, as it is smooth, comfortable, can work wet or dry, and leaves you with the smoothest shave you can have from an electric. I've never shaved better in my life, and plan on sticking with Panasonic shavers in the future.
  417. I purchased this shaver to replace my existing 6 year old Panasonic. I was not disappointed. The same quality that I found with the original razor was easily rediscovered with the new unit. The only reason the old unit was retired was that I was due for a new razor/foil set (approx $30). After discounts, the new unit was only ~$40 more -- so upgrade time! The new unit is faster, charges quicker, and runs quieter (great with 2 small kids). Another great razor from Panasonic -- highly recommended!
  418. The shaver is great. I need to shave everyday and the traditional razors give me a lot of bumps. This shaver is much better and gives a much closer shave than my old Norelco. The cleaning cycle is noisy, but it does not need to run very often, so it doesn't bother. Definitely worth the money.
  419. Bought this to upgrade a previous panasonic wet/dry shaver. This shaver is even better if that is possible. Highly recommend this product.
  420. I use the shaver for both my face and my head... It is more efficient and effective than any other shaver I have ever owned...
  421. Foil just won't cut rogue hairs a few days old. You need to use the trimmer all over the place.<br />Also it doesn't operate while charging.
  422. it's kind of good.<br />shaving well and easy to Maintenance also price is not high. I'm satisfied it. thank you.
  423. Panasonic always seems to hit a home run with their products. This razor works great, in wet or dry. Since it is lithium powered, it holds the power all the way down, unlike Ni-Cad which starts losing power as the battery loses charge. Do you really need the charging/cleaning base? You could argue it is a gimmic, since you can easily clean the razor under the sink faucet. Maybe the cleaning system does something that just running water doesn't. I don't know, but the base works fine.
  424. This is a great razor!nafter the initial 2-3 weeks of your skin getting used to the new type of shaving (if you're switching from a traditional razor) it gives a nice close shave with very little skin irritation. The upkeep (soap cartridges) and replacement parts (razors and foil) are very low cost and you will definitely be better off in the long run when you compare to buying shaving cream and triple blade razor heads every few weeks.
  425. As far as electric razors go, this one is up there in terms of efficiency and comfort. There's only one significant drawback, it's LOUD. Loud to the point where you worry about waking people up if you use it early in the morning.
  426. I understand that electric shavers don't get quite as close as a real razor. After using this shaver, I still feel like I have approximately a noon shadow. It just isn't close enough. I'm back to the real razor, and this one will be used for other areas.
  427. I gave up electric shavers years ago but tried this on a lark and am impressed. I think the abiltiy to use in the shower is a big plus. I still have trouble shaving my neck and the far sides of my jaw. I hope that will change as my face adjusts to electric shaving. I have noticed that i have less shadow at teh end of the day, suggesting that I am getting a closer shave than baldes. I read somewhere that blade shaving looks closer at first because it causes the skin to swell, but that wears off after a short period of time. That could well be true. I'm sticking with this electric.
  428. The Winner Is... The Panasonic ES8109S 3-blade - barely. Put the Remington blades and cutter (keeping the center blade of the Panasonic) on a Panasonic 13,000 RPM shaver and you would have the World's best electric shaver. The Remington shaved a little closer than the Panasonic and provided a faster shave. However, the difficulty in cleaning, noise and lack of a charging base tipped me to the Panasonic as the final choice. This is a review of three Panasonic models; ES8243A (4-blade), ES8109S (3-blade) and ES7109, the Remington MS2-390, the Norelco 8260 CC and the Braun Series 5 8995 (8985 & 8975 only differ in displays and cleaning). I have an average beard and have been using electric shavers (foils and rotaries) over 30 years. The models here are no better than any of the other higher quality shavers I've owned. It takes about 10 minutes (no shaver will give you a first-pass close shave) to get to that good dry shave (with or without pre-electric gels/oils) and you do have to put pressure on to get a close shave. This means recharging every 4-5 days. Gels/oils do make the process easier - not faster - and I have reviewed six of them on their Amazon sites. ES8109S: This 3-blade shaver gives a very close shave, with some work. It does give off a higher pitch `whine', while shaving, that is somewhat annoying, but is not what I would consider noisy. Nor is the cleaning operation noisy. Based upon other reviewers, I was expecting it to sound like a lawn mower, but it is just an occasional buzzing noise as it cleans. The \\"Arc Foil\\" design slows shaving (see discussion, below). ES8243A: I had hoped that the four blades of the Panasonic ES8243A just might be able to give a superior shave. As it turns out, the large four-blade surface is like trying to keep the end of a 2x4 on your face. It makes cutting in the areas where you don't have a lot of skin area (chin, jaw line, upper lip, base of sideburns, etc) more difficult. In fact, I think that the fourth blade in the middle actually interferes with a better shave and these two middle blades are not as good as the primary cutters. The \\"Arc Foil\\" design makes it even slower (see discussion, below). Another future problem with the 4-blade system is that you'll want to buy a new shaver when your blades and foil need to be replaced. What kind of an idiot is going to spend 80% of the cost of a new shaver just to get a set of new cutter blades and foil? All in all: the ES8243A 4-blade is a poor value. ES7109S: The flat design of the foil is a better design than the \\"Arc Foil\\" (see below). Unfortunately, this shaver has an under-powered motor and the floating head that cannot be locked. Panasonic discussion: Panasonic had developed an outstanding shaver line some ten years ago. My old ES8067 still shaves closer than this new \\"NANO Technology\\"- a misnomer (marketing gimmick). I think the reason is that Panasonic's older models came with cutting blades with the individual blades having been about half the width of all of Panasonic's newer cutting blades (including replacements). This means more surface area on the newer blades and that means less cutting. Remington has the ideal blades (that Panasonic used to make) and it shows in closer cutting and less time spent doing so. Additionally, these new Panasonic \\"Arc Foil\\" shavers have the foil curving AWAY from your face at the ends of the foil, further decreasing exposure to the blades and requiring many more passes to cover the same area. Unfortunately, Panasonic puts their better motor (13,000 RPMs) only on these ill-conceived \\"Arc Foil\\" designs. Battery time on the Panasonics is the shortest of all shavers reviewed here. The Panasonic trimmers are so narrow, on all of these models, that you will not be able to trim sideburns with one attempt. You will have to re-position the trimmer to get what you missed. This increases the probability that you will get an uneven sideburn. The Remington MS2-390 has the blades that thePanasonics should have (and did have years ago): flat foil area (not \\"Arc Foiled\\"), good length (25% longer) and ultra thin cutting blades. As a result, closeness of the shave is better and time spent is shorter. This is, however, the loudest (and it is loud) of all shavers and there are no bells and whistles. Using a pre-shave oil/gel will gum up the blades, as with any shaver, but these blades pop off with even the slightest brushing so be prepared to watch them fall into the sink with every cleaning attempt. A charging stand would greatly increase the convenience of this shaver. Remington did a poor job with the details. The Braun Series 5 8995 tries hard (you can hear noticeable slowing when necessary pressure is applied, like a lawn mower when it reaches thicker grass), but it doesn't get quite as close as the Panasonics or Remington without leaving a stronger burning sensation after the shave. The Braun can also leave burn marks and even cuts (nose and lips) that will bleed. Odd: you would think that, with it getting so close as to actually burn the skin, it would also give a closer shave. I suppose this is proof that shavers cannot \\"lift\\" hairs to cut better. Additionally, the design of the handle is inferior, making positioning more difficult. It does have a much wider trimmer and longer battery life between charges, though. The Norelco 8260 CC: I used this rotary-type of shaver for many years during the 80's. I switched to foil and found I could get a closer shave. This is still the case. Additionally, because of the circular blades, it is somewhat difficult to target certain spots for cleanup. However, this is the quietest shaver. PS: don't accept the nonsense about giving your face 30 days to adjust, unless you are coming off a blade. If you are accustomed to an electric shaver, you only need a week or two to determine the difference. The only thing magical about 30 days is that you can no longer return it for a refund - what a coincidence!
  429. I bought a refurbished ES8109 shaver on Ebay. So far, after 2 weeks of using it, I'm thrilled. I've been using electric shavers for over 15 years. During that period, I've almost exclusively used rotaries. However, I kept buying new ones because they either broke, shave quality wasn't good, etc. I was most recently using a Norelco shaver (Speed XL I think) with a jet clean unit. I never was crazy about the shave it gave me, and the cleaning unit was messy and eventually stopped working. Very frustrating. I liked having a cleaning unit, so I decided to give the Panasonic a try. With my very first shave I could tell a huge difference. A nice close shave with little to no irritation. It even worked well the tough spots (like on the neck). My face never felt so smooth. I also love being able to shave in the shower again (all the wet/dry shavers I've used in the past died in 1-2 years, hopefully not this one). And the cleaning unit was awesome. Easy to use, not messy like the Norelco one, and it even dries the razor. The cleaning solution is pretty cheap on Amazon too (about $10 for a 3 month supply). One suggestion. I've been using shave oil (try American Crew, or Kiehl's Shave Oil) and it's worked very well. I tried shaving one day with Edge Gel, and maybe it shaved too close. I ended up with a lot of irritation, even drew some blood in places. My face felt like it was burning. I went back to the shave oil again, and voila, another great shave.
  430. As the title mentions spending higher than average on a product doesn't always mean you will get a higher than average product. And in my opinion the Panasonic ES8109 is one of those cases. For the positives: Very fast smooth motor, much more comfortable shave overall compared to the $30 shavers I have used in the past. It comes with a built in trimmer to edge up around hairlines/etc which is always a plus, but even standard on the cheaper models. The LCD display is neat and gives an accurate measurement of the battery life remaining in which I start to charge it around 10%. Speaking of charging it does come with one of the fancy smancy self cleaner's 'ala' more profit for Panasonic on accessories(need's cartridges). For the negatives: Honestly, I could swear I've gotten a closer shave with the Panasonic ES4026NC ($25 Shave mind you). The upside of the ES8109 is that is does to a better job at getting neck hairs, but still has yet to impress me. For the most part I have to work at it to get most hairs, about 95% at best. It still cannot get all of them and this is the biggest downfall on top of the OK quality shave, really nothing to brag about on this shaver. Also the first cartridge didn't even last the whole month, and this was after hearing someone being able to use it twice over. I reinserted the cleaner cartridge to see if I could get more out of it but ran into a couple problems. The first being that yes, the cartridge was really used up, after it was done 'cleaning' quite a bit of hairs were still around the razor. Secondly, the station will not let you select the clean option once it recognizes a dirty cartridge. All in all on the clean/charge station, I honestly think its a waste of a plug and money on cartridges. And as a funny little side note, the adapter plug does make an annoying high pitched squealy noise. Of course it's not loud and is inaudible probably more than 4 feet away in a quite room, but still, sounds like cheap parts to me. Andthere you have it, take my opinions as you will but I just find for the price this shaver sells at, far exceeds what it can actually do. Like I said it isn't all bad but at the end of the day I rate this shaver as \\"It's OK\\".
  431. My husband has very sensitive skin and he is pleased that it does not irritate his face. He says that it works best when used with shaving cream. He likes the cleaning feature, although it took him a while to get used to it - the directions weren't as good as they should have been.
  432. After of over one year of use, I am going to throw it away. It is noisy (angry bee hive) needs a razor blade to get remaining stubble to a cleaner shave and side burn trimmer is useless. I would never recommend this product no matter how well it is recommended.
  433. This product was a good buy. While it did not provide as close of a shave as I hoped for, it did not irritate my face and cleanup was easy. It takes about five minutes to fully shave with this product, I have found that I have to go over areas of my face multiple times.<br /><br />The cleaning function of the base works well, but it is very noisy and takes a long time. The battery life of the shaver is more than adequate, it should last for between five and seven shaves.<br /><br />Although this product is touted as suitable for wet use, I found that the shave quality suffers greatly unless you rinse off the shaver and your face every couple passes.<br /><br />Overall a good product with a moderate price.
  434. i bought this for my boyfriend to use for when he stood over at my place. he has baby facial hair (i make him shave his barely-a-man beard) so i couldn't really give it a honest review. but last christmas my parents came to stay for the holidays, and well, my dad took the darn shaver! i didn't realize it was gone until my boyfriend asked to use it and i eventually asked my parents if they saw it (apparently my father believed he should take the liberty of possessing all non-feminine items in my home for as long he can benefit from them). anyhow, my dad raves how great it is and how it doesn't bother his skin at all (i noticed a difference after inspecting my dad's face that wasn't as red or irritated). my dad is in his fifties and has a beard that can grow almost as long as santa claus, so i was happy for him. so in my books, this is a true winner (plus i only paid $70 in total for a brand new set from amazon). so try to get it with the lowest price available and you, too, can have an excellent product at a great steal.
  435. I am 71 and was finding it increasingly difficult to shave with a razor as beard was not only grayish white but harder to cut. Perhaps any electric shaver would be better than what I was doing. So based on reviewers comments on Amazon I purchased this shaver and observe that not only do I get a closer shave, which surprised me, but a more comfortable shave.
  436. I have no complains about this shaver. Very good quality as expected from Panasonic. The neatest thing about it is the care of it -cleaning- you just put it in the cradle push a button and the next time you use it is nice and clean.
  437. I have been using the Panasonic ES8109 for about 7 months now. Prior to this I was a Norelco user for nearly 25 years. Why did I decide to try something different? I found that over the last 10 years or so the quality of the Norelco products and the shave I received were both decidely in decline. Even right out of the box, the Norelco shave quality was marginal, and my face still felt like 100 grit sandpaper after working it over for 5 minutes. The Panasonic was an entirely different story. I have always used a dry shave, and the Panasonic gave me a smooth shave in the same amount of time. I use the Panasonic hydrasonic cleaning device that came with it whenever the shaver gets around a 60-70% charge on it, which in my case is about 5 shaves. It still is giving me a great shave. The sideburn trimmer does a better job than the Norelco and operates at a higher trimming speed. I am on my third box of cleaner inserts for the cleaning unit, and each insert seems to last about 3 weeks. I bought the replacements through Amazon. The unit restores the shaving head unit and screen to their original condition. I have not noticed any deterioration of the blades so far, unlike the Norelco that seemed to fade after 4-5 months and you had press very hard to get even a marginal shave! I would recommend this shaver for a good, close shave. I'm impressed with the quality of workmanship.
  438. I almost never write reviews, so why am I writing one now ? Because I think a lot of people will benefit from what I have to say. I've been using the Norelco Spectra 8894XL rotary for years. I guess if it's good for 007 it's good enough for me. Movie advertising really does work. Before that I was a blade person. I still use the blade occasionally when I want a smooth shave. The Norelco never could come close to the blade even with the Spectra set to the closest shave setting. So why did I go to the electric shaver. Speed and convenience. Don't need to worry about packing shaving cream when I fly. It still always took at least 6 minutes for the Spectra to do a reasonable job. Three to four years ago, when I had to replace the Spectra blades I thought I would take a look at the foil shavers. I went on to Amazon and read the reviews. There really did not appear to be a major difference between the rotary and foil products. Each had enough offsetting pluses an minuses so I didn't really see a clear winner. I stayed with the Spectra. Finally , a few weeks ago my Spectra battery died. I opened up the case, saw that the battery was basically soldered to a circuit board. Thanks a lot Norelco. Time to look at some alternative options. First thing I did was go to Amazon. They have the most thorough reviews for these types of products on the web. Reviews from a lot of other web sites are basically copy and pasted from Amazon. After I read the reviews, and looked at the distribution of ratings, it appeared that the Panasonic foil product line was getting consistently higher reviews vs other foils and the rotaries. When you see the number of reviews rated 5 or 4 vs the number at 1 or 2, and the 5/4's outnumber the 1/2's by almost 9 to 1, it's time to start paying attention. And this wasn't just for the Panasonic foil I bought, which was the ES8109S, but all of the Panasonics were getting consistently high reviews. One recommendation, Amazon, is you should come up with anaverage rating number. Just helps a little, especially if there are a large number of reviews. I settled with the ES8109S. Best price for the features and technology, including the cleaning unit. Just $20 more than the bare bones shaver. If the cleaner becomes a pain, just don't use it. For $104 on Amazon, it was worth a try. Got the shaver yesterday. I read the directions. Panasonic needs to hire some better technical writers. Their instructions are in a treasure map format. It's all there, but you need to cipher to break the code. Just a few more sentences and better organized layout, and I think they could sell more units, especially if people download the manual before they buy a product. I have an advanced engineering degree and it still took me an inordinate amount to time to figure out what the hell they were talking about. What's a \\"course\\" ? Replace that word with \\"sequence\\" and use some other American English words in some other instances and the manual will be more readable. Panasonic, hire some good American English technical writers. Please. Finally, I set up the shaver and the cleaner while heeding all the warnings delineated in the manual. Nothing blew up or smoked, or spilled. That was a good sign. Charged the unit overnight and tried it out in the morning. I was more than impressed. How can I make up for all the time I lost using the stupid Spectra ? It took me less than half the time, under 3 minutes, to get a shave that was far better than what the Spectra will ever be capable of, and that's coming from a foil \\"virgin\\". FYI, I don't have a very heavy beard, but enough to frighten the cat in the morning. Face burn, not a problem with this unit. The shave rivaled the blade. Rotary users, take a look the this Panasonic line next time you're in the market. The learning curve is non-existent. I was a little reluctant making the change to a foil, and I'm glad I switched.
  439. This shaver replaced a Braun. So far I have to say that this one is far superior!
  440. i bought this because i shave my head, and my earlier norelco was worn out. i did not realize how worn out my old shaver was until i used this one. the shave is really very good and surprisingly close. the unit is easy to clean, including a mode where you rinse it and then just put it in the cradle and select the dry option. the battery lasts long enough to do about 4 or 5 days of shaving with it. the only real drawback is that the straight cutting surface (as opposed to the floating heads of the norelco) means that you have to make a lot of passes over curved surfaces like the head, and it can be kind of harsh on thin skin. as my skin toughens up a bit and i learn a new pattern, this is getting better. overall a very good shaver.
  441. I reserched a TON of electric razors as I did a few years ago. I had been using a Panasonic and LOVED my old razor, but it gave out on me. The reviews for this model were so good, I trusted them as I trusted the reviews that were accurate about my last panasonic. Unfortunately, this razor is TERRIBLE for my sensitive skin. I'm a female, with pale skin and thick dark hair, and I suffer from folliculitis which means when I shave I get infected hair follicles. That's why I HAVE to use an electric razor. Well, this razor causes such awful ingrowns my legs have constant scabs because I need to dig the hairs out from underneath my skin. NOT GOOD!!!! I wish I knew why it caused ingrowns because I can't figure it out. Also, reviews stated that the shave is such a close clean shave that you need one pass... uhh, not with my experience. I had to keep going back and forth over the same area about 4-5 times to get all the hair shaved. So for me, wish to GOD I would not have bought this razor. It wasn't cheap and now I have to go looking for another one. : (
  442. I bought this for my husband as a Christmas gift. He loves it and comments frequently about how well it works. He uses it in the shower and above the sink. It cleans itself well and he charges it less than once a week. I think it does a great job of shaving closely and taking care of his sensitive skin. He's had it since Christmas and has not even thought about replacing any parts or the blade - it still works like a champ! We're both very happy with this purchase.
  443. Best shaver ever. close shave and zero irritation. I have sensitive skin and had an issue of ingrown hairs, but now I get none. Highly reccommended!
  444. I have been using this razor for a year and half now. It still works great. I have been changing out the hydroclean insert about every 3 or 4 months and the blades once a year. I have found that squirting a little hand soap on top of the blades and running the razor about 20 seconds every now and then helps keep the blades fresh smelling. The charging/cleaning stand is a very good idea and gives you a good place to store it between shaves. This razor is not as good as the Norelco on shaving the curves under your neck so I keep a waterproof Norelco in the shower to \\"finish up' while I take a shower. Hey, it works for me!
  445. I bought this shaver because it was the cheapest self-cleaning model I could find. I was not disappointed. Not having to clean it is a huge time saver, and it's surprisingly gentle. I've actually managed to cut myself with electric shavers before (don't ask me how that works, I don't know) but not with this one. A huge bonus to it is that it's able to work through a few days' growth. Previously, I had to use the trimmers on electric shavers if I'd forgotten to shave for a few days. With this model, I simply have to very lightly run it back and forth along the grain (as per the instructions) and it is able to cut down my beard millimeter by millimeter, much less hassle than using a razor. Highly recommended.
  446. This is the first electric razor that I've purchased and been satisfied with. Granted the previous 2 were rougly $50 or $60, so you can't expect anything more than average from them. The price I bought it at (approx. $110) was a steal for its simplicity and usability. It's a wet/dry razor, so I always use it in the shower. Drop it into the cleaner/charger and it's ready to go the next day (my job requires a face as smooth as a baby's caboose). It does take awhile for it to go through the cleaning cycle, but I doubt that the majority of (wo)men using this razor need to shave every 2 1/2 to 3 hours. Now the big disappointment with the razor has been the quality of the shave. On a good day, it gets about 90% of the job done. On a bad day, probably 75%. I have to come in and clean up with a hand razor.
  447. This thing rocks!! I have tryed others but they do not compare.. 13,000 rpms!!! DO I NEED TO SAY MORE?
  448. I have had this razor for about three weeks now and am either going to return it or give it away for the ES-LA93-K. It's good on my face but not on my neck. It's OK as a dry razor but one would think that using it wet would give a close shave. It does NOT!!! I don't have a thick beard, just an average one.   449. This is my First Electric Razor.. and I am 30 now.. so it explains that I did not want to try one because of the sensitive skin.
